columns.text: The goal of this task is to explain why acquiring firm stockholders seem to benefit very little from takeovers.

In this section, we find a reference to several studies that have examined the gains and losses in stock value around the time of merger announcements. 

Based on this, an explanation of the benefits of acquiring company shareholders after mergers and acquisitions explains that shareholders in bidder firms seem to neither win nor lose very much, at least on average. 

There is the puzzle! The main reasons offered in the explanation are: 

- If managers of bidding firms tend to overestimate the gains from acquisition, then shareholders will have losses instead of expected gains from the merger.

- Bidding firm is usually a larger firm so its percentage gains are much lower. 
- Management may not be acting in the interest of shareholders when it attempts to acquire other firms.

- The prices paid in acquisitions fully reflect the value of the acquired firms. In other words, the sellers capture all of the gains.

- The announced intentions to engage in merger “programs” long before that announce specific acquisitions makes that information to the market about the bidding firm is not updated, creating anticipated gains from mergers.

***Let's summarize our findings***:

Acquiring firm stockholders seems to benefit very little from takeovers and this is a complicated finding. The main reasons are that managers often overestimate the expected gains from acquisition, acquiring companies are usually larger than the target ones and sometimes information in the market about companies is not updated so expected gains could be overestimated.

textbook.authors: Bradford D. Jordan, Randolph W. Westerfield, Stephen A. Ross
textbook.title: Fundamentals of Corporate Finance
